message.abstract:
<jats:p>
            The mechanism of tetracycline resistance mediated by R931 (a
            <jats:italic>Pseudomonas aeruginosa</jats:italic>
            R factor not yet successfully transferred to
            <jats:italic>Escherichia coli</jats:italic>
            recipients) was examined. In strain 931 (R931) (minimal inhibitory concentration [MIC] 200 μg/ml) significant tetracycline uptake did not occur until 100 μg of tetracycline per ml was included in uptake studies. The introduction of R931 into strain 280 resulted in a significant decline in
            <jats:sup>3</jats:sup>
            H-tetracycline uptake. In both strains 931 (R931) and 280 (R931), a further reduction in tetracycline uptake resulted from pre-incubation with 1 μg of tetracycline per ml. Tetracycline resistance in R
            <jats:sup>−</jats:sup>
            <jats:italic>P. aeruginosa</jats:italic>
            strains 1731, 1885, and 494, considered to be of chromosomal origin, was associated with a lack of tetracycline uptake until the MIC of the strain was obtained. No evidence of tetracycline inactivation or ribosomal resistance was detected in R
            <jats:sup>−</jats:sup>
            or R
            <jats:sup>+</jats:sup>
            strains. The MIC for R
            <jats:sup>−</jats:sup>
            strains was generally about 25 μg/ml and that for R
            <jats:sup>+</jats:sup>
            strains was 75 to 200 μg/ml.
          </jats:p>
title: Mechanisms of R Factor R931 and Chromosomal Tetracycline Resistance in Pseudomonas aeruginosa

affiliation.name: Department of Medical Bacteriology, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Canada
Department of Medical Bacteriology, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Canada
